abstracts.cdata!:
The unusual crisis context of the
            operation and its implications to both the project design
            and implementation make the evaluation of the outcome
            somewhat problematical. The World Bank adapted the various
            project components to accommodate the frequent changes and
            urgent needs that could not be financed through the
            government's budget due to unavailability of funds. It
            was under extraordinary circumstances--the mounting crisis,
            riots on the streets, the deep political and policy changes,
            the lack of budgetary resources for urgent technical
            assistance, and the coordination challenges within and among
            international financial institutions--that the objectives
            and components of the project were designed and implemented;
            and under which their outcome should be assessed. In this
            context, the project outcome was unsatisfactory and the
            project unsustainable. Although both Bank and Borrower
            performances were rated as unsatisfactory, this simply
            stated conclusion belies the extraordinary efforts
            undertaken by both parties who were overwhelmed by a severe
            financial crisis and a rapidly deteriorating political
            situation. Lessons learned were several, including: For
            crisis response lending, flexible design and rapid or timely
            delivery are critical. Although a team specializing in
            financial crisis management (the SFO team) was created to
            deal with the East Asian crisis, this type of operation has
            proven to be unsustainable within the Bank's
            organizational structure and procedure.
